definition:
Whereas a simple addition of unit fractions with the terms of
Sylvester’s sequence as denominators gives as a result the integer 1, an
alternating sum $$\sum_{i = 0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^i}{a_i - 1}$$ (where
$a_i$ is the $i$th term of Sylvester’s sequence) gives the
transcendental number known as *Cahen’s constant* (after Eugène Cahen)
with an approximate decimal value of
0.643410546288338026182254307757564763286587860268239505987 (see A118227
in Sloane’s OEIS). Alternatively, we can express Cahen’s constant as
$$\sum_{j = 0}^\infty \frac{1}{a_{2j}}.$$ The recurrence relation
$b_{n + 2} = {b_n}^2b_{n + 1} + b_n$ gives us the terms for the
continued fraction representation of this constant:
$$1 + \frac{1}{{b_0}^2 + \frac{1}{{b_1}^2 + \frac{1}{{b_3}^2 + \, \cdots}}}$$
